# Zazen
#self/spirituality/zen/zazen 
## Summary
Zazen, or meditation, is the act of sitting, and the practice of welcoming [awakening](Awake%20(Zen).md). Zazen is practiced in Zen Buddhism. The word Zazen literally means "sitting meditation".

## My Meditation Practice
I have practiced meditation intermittently, more off than on than I'd prefer, for about 10 years. I like to sit in the full lotus position on a meditation cushion, or zafu, placed atop a zabuton.

> ![](data:image/png;base64,)
> *A zafu on a zabuton*

I like to then take a few cleansing breaths to release tension in my body and relax my muscles prior to meditation. Then I simply sit and observe my breathing without controlling it, and exist as an awake being in the world. When my thoughts drift to one topic or another, I draw myself back to my breath. I haven't found a better way to meditate than this.

In the past I have experimented with counting breaths, and guided meditation, among other techniques. These can be beneficial as well, but for me the best method is simply to sit and be awake while breathing.

## Posture
Posture is perhaps the most important part of meditation, as it serves as your foundation while you sit. Improper posture will throw off the entire meditation session, and may even cause you to end it prematurely. There are many positions which are traditional and offer various benefits. The correct position to sit in is the one that is comfortable for you, that allows you to breathe easily, be fully awake and not fall asleep, and one that you can hold for an extended period of time without moving.

I like to sit in the lotus position with the back of my hands against my knees and palms up, middle fingers touching thumbs, back and neck straight and erect. I like to close my eyes halfway [^1] and touch my tongue to the roof of my mouth while relaxing my jaw.

> ![](data:image/png;base64,)
> *The lotus position*


[^1]: I actually used to prefer to close my eyes for meditation, but I had heard it is not discouraged to do so in the Zen school of Buddhism, due to the fact we are not closing ourselves off from the world when we meditate, but rather experiencing ourselves in it. I half-close them instead as a compromise.
